# Chapter 1: The Beginning

Kenji walked into the room. Tired didn't cover it — the day had hollowed him out the way ten hours of watching an AI do your job hollows everyone eventually. The room was dark. He flipped the switch. Light hit surfaces that hadn't changed since morning, which was the problem.

"Welcome home," the AI assistant said, flat as a foreclosure notice. "Your vitality levels are nominal."

"Nobody asked," Kenji muttered.

Kenji dropped into his desk chair. The terminal's cursor blinked at him with the patience of something that didn't need sleep, didn't need food, and didn't need him.

`This is fine. Everything is fine. I'm a biological placeholder and the machine does my job better than I ever could. At least I have a subscription to breathe the air. The subscription costs more than the air is worth.`

The pod hummed in the corner. Green gel shifted inside it — not sloshing, not still, but waiting the way only expensive technology waits: with the quiet confidence that you'll come to it eventually, because it already owns the hours you haven't spent yet.
